# Arpeggio: 13th in B

An arpeggio is the playing of the notes of a chord in succession, often ascending or descending. The 13th arpeggio is an extension of the basic major, minor, or dominant arpeggios and adds the 13th note of the B major scale to the chord.

## Notes and Intervals:
The B major 13th arpeggio consists of the notes B (root), D# (major third), F# (perfect fifth), A# (major seventh), and G# (major thirteenth). This arpeggio creates a rich and colorful sound due to the added tension of the 13th note.

## Genre and Musical Flavor:
The B major 13th arpeggio is often used in jazz and R&B music to add sophistication and complexity to chord progressions and solos. It has a lush and jazzy flavor that can evoke feelings of elegance and romance.

## Example Songs:
1. "**All The Things You Are**" by Jerome Kern - This jazz standard features the B major 13th arpeggio in various sections of the chord progression.
2. "**Just the Two of Us**" by Bill Withers - This R&B classic uses the B major 13th arpeggio in the smooth guitar lines throughout the song.
3. "**Blue Bossa**" by Kenny Dorham - A popular jazz standard that incorporates the B major 13th arpeggio in the chord changes, enhancing the harmonic depth of the piece.
